content.text: Walking independently begins with walking around an object and using it for support (cruising). With time, the infant gains a sense of confidence in their walk as their sense of balance improves with practice.
A balanced and stable walk is the basis for advanced movements like jumping, running and climbing.

If you see that your baby is having a hard time achieving this milestone by the age of 15 months, you should consult with your pediatrician or an infant development guide to learn how to help your baby. These important abilities are the foundation of their physical, sensory and emotional needs. Here are some signs that your baby may need help:

ul: Walking is still global after two months and looks uncomfortable.
Feet turn inward or outward and not straight (as if baby will walk on the side of the foot; known as clubfoot).
Walking with the back bending forward and the knees bent.
